elements.title: Malan Bridge (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that according to legend, Malan Bridge (pictured) was built by two mythical princesses who mixed egg shells with clay to create a bridge stronger than steel?

elements.title: Aaron Pike (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Aaron Pike has competed in wheelchair racing at three Summer Paralympics, and in both biathlon and cross-country skiing at two Winter Paralympics?

elements.title: Geistliches Lied (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the opening of Geistliches Lied by Johannes Brahms possibly references Clara Schumann's fantasy of playing her husband's music on the organ?

elements.title: Horace Harral (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Horace Harral engraved "one of the most famous photographs of the nineteenth century", a portrait of Isambard Kingdom Brunel, for publication in the Illustrated Times?

elements.title: Rhodesia Information Centre (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Rhodesia Information Centre spread propaganda about Rhodesia in Australia?

elements.title: Sevastijan Dabović (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that bishop Nikolaj Velimirović called Sevastijan Dabović the greatest Serbian missionary of modern times?

elements.title: One potato, two potato (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the counting-out rhyme "One potato, two potato" is more than 135 years old?

elements.title: Mahama Refugee Camp (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that thousands of people who fled Burundi have taken refuge in Rwanda's Mahama Refugee Camp, but only one has competed in the Paralympics?
